content: The "Reducing Environmental Barriers to Unified Infrastructure and Land Development Act of 2011 Act" or the "REBUILD Act" assigns federal environmental review responsibilities to states for certain projects within the state. The "REBUILD Act" allows states to assume federal environmental review responsibilities for specific projects with written agreement from the responsible Federal official. The "REBUILD Act" allows states to assume federal environmental review responsibilities for specific projects with written agreement from the responsible Federal official. States must adhere to the same procedural and substantive requirements as the responsible Federal official. Any responsibilities not explicitly assumed by the state remain with the Federal official. This section does not preempt or interfere with any existing authority. The "REBUILD Act" allows states to assume federal environmental review responsibilities for specific projects with written agreement from the responsible Federal official. States must adhere to the same procedural and substantive requirements as the official. The Act does not interfere with any existing agency authority under applicable law. State regulations must be established within 180 days of enactment, outlining project details for assumption of responsibility. States applying for assumption of federal environmental review responsibilities under the "REBUILD Act" must provide verification of financial resources, evidence of public comment solicitation, and give notice of their intent to submit the application at least 30 days prior. The State must publish its complete application and solicit public comment in accordance with state public notice laws. A Federal official can only approve the State's application if regulatory requirements are met, the State has the necessary capabilities, and the State agency with primary jurisdiction over projects is involved. The State must enter into a written agreement with the responsible Federal official before assuming jurisdiction over covered projects. If the responsibility would have required consultation with another Federal agency, the views of that agency must be solicited. The agreement must be executed by the Governor or the head of the State agency and in a form approved by the responsible Federal official. The State must enter into a written agreement with the responsible Federal official before assuming jurisdiction over covered projects. The agreement must be in a prescribed form and include the State's agreement to assume responsibilities, consent to federal court jurisdiction, and certification of state laws authorizing necessary actions. The agreement includes the State's agreement to assume responsibilities, consent to federal court jurisdiction, and certification of state laws authorizing necessary actions. The United States district courts have exclusive jurisdiction over any civil action against a State for failure to carry out responsibilities under this section, governed by legal standards. The responsible Federal official has the right to intervene in any action, and a State assuming responsibility will be solely liable until the termination of such assumption. The State cannot assume rulemaking authority under any Federal law. To ensure compliance with agreements, the responsible Federal official conducts semiannual and annual audits for States participating in the program. Audits are made public for a 30-day comment period, with responses due within 60 days. The responsible Federal official must respond to public comments within 60 days after the comment period ends. Each official must submit an annual report to Congress on the administration of this section. The official can terminate an agreement with a State if the State is not fulfilling its responsibilities. The responsible Federal official must notify the State of noncompliance and provide a 30-day period for corrective action. If the State fails to take satisfactory corrective action, the official can terminate the agreement. The responsible Federal official oversees projects requiring approval or permits, including those by the Secretary of the Army.
